DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text that describes the Child-Pugh Classification (CPC) Ascites score which is used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis. Although it was originally used to predict mortality during surgery, it is now used to determine the prognosis, as well as the required strength of treatment and the necessity of liver transplantation._Annotation used to indicate that the size or magnitude of something was determined by comparison to a standard._A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis. Although it was originally used to predict mortality during surgery, it is now used to determine the prognosis, as well as the required strength of treatment and the necessity of liver transplantation.

Concepts.definition: Used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis. Although it was originally used to predict mortality during surgery, it is now used to determine the prognosis, as well as the required strength of treatment and the necessity of liver transplantation.

Property.preferredDefinition: Measurement; the size or magnitude of something.:A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

Concepts.definition: Annotation used to indicate the size or magnitude of something that was determined by comparison to a standard.
A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Process and results associated with self-reported measures and instruments, surveys, other tools

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis. Although it was originally used to predict mortality during surgery, it is now used to determine the prognosis, as well as the required strength of treatment and the necessity of liver transplantation._Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity.  The fluid may be serous, hemorrhagic, or the result of tumor metastasis to the peritoneum. _A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.

Concepts.definition: Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Gentle or temperate in nature or degree.

Concepts.definition: Gentle or temperate in nature or degree.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

Concepts.definition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis. Although it was originally used to predict mortality during surgery, it is now used to determine the prognosis, as well as the required strength of treatment and the necessity of liver transplantation.:Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity.  The fluid may be serous, hemorrhagic, or the result of tumor metastasis to the peritoneum. -- 2004:A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

Concepts.definition: Used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis. Although it was originally used to predict mortality during surgery, it is now used to determine the prognosis, as well as the required strength of treatment and the necessity of liver transplantation.
The accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity, which may be serous, hemorrhagic, or the result of tumor metastasis to the peritoneum.
A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: 1/10/18 jk createdfor NWU2016-08-02 to reflect textual PVs per instrument.

DataElement.changeDescription: 1/10/18 jk Created for NWU2016-08-02 to match textual description of ascites score based on the Child-Pugh Classification (CPC). Format for NWU2016-08-02 data collection.
